720.50 metres to [[Berri-UQAM (Montreal Metro)|Berri-UQAM]] |addresses=940, Sanguinet Street |intersections= Sanguinet Street / Viger Avenue [http://www.stm.info/English/metro/Champ-de-Mars.pdf Champ-de-Mars Station Neighbourhood Map] |}} '''Champ-de-Mars''' is a [[metro station|station]] on the [[Line 2 Orange (Montreal Metro)|Orange Line]] of the [[Montreal Metro]] [[Rapid transit|rapid transit system]], operated by the [[SociÃ©tÃ© de transport de MontrÃ©al]] (STM). It is located in [[Old Montreal]] in the borough of [[Ville-Marie (Montreal)|Ville-Marie]] in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]] [http://www.stm.info/English/metro/a-m12.htm Champ-de-Mars Metro Station]. The station opened on October 14, 1966, as part of the original network of the metro. == Overview == The metro station, designed by Adalbert Niklewicz, is a normal [[side platform]] station, built in [[Tunnel#Cut-and-cover|open cut]] due to the presence of weak Utica [[shale]] in the surrounding [[rock (geology)|rock]]. Its entrance is located near a series of [[tunnel]]s that cross the [[Autoroute Ville-Marie]], giving access to [[Old Montreal]]. == Architecture and art == [[image:Montreal - Metro Champs-de-Mars, panorama-20050329.jpg|left|thumb|400px|center|The antique stained glass, installed in 1968, Automatiste painter Marcelle Ferron.]] One of the most important [[Work of art|artwork]]s in the metro, a set of [[stained glass]] windows by noted Quebec artist [[Marcelle Ferron]], illuminates the mezzanine of this station. These windows, one of the artist's masterpieces and her most famous work, were given by the Government of Quebec in 1968. They were the first work of non-figurative art to be commissioned for the metro, representing the first official entrance of [[Les Automatistes|Automatist]] art in the system. ==Origin of the name== This station is named for [[Champ de Mars, Montreal|Champ-de-Mars]], a public park facing [[Montreal City Hall]]. The name is the French term for a military parade ground. It was formerly crossed by the city's fortifications, demolished in the 19th century, the foundations of which can still be seen. It was later turned into a parking lot, which was replaced by a park in 1980s. ==Connecting bus routes== {{Main|SociÃ©tÃ© de transport de MontrÃ©al}} {{Main|List of Montreal Bus Routes}}
